content.title: 50年前、私の大学時代は厳しいものでした。そして、エリート主義は悪化しています。
content.desc: It’s no surprise that our top universities doggedly refuse to acknowledge their role in perpetuating the ugly truth about modern Britain: money and the right class still get you access and a seat at the top table. When it comes to choosing which pupils to accept for a highly prized place at Oxbridge, pedigree is everything. The Sutton Trust has discovered that just eight elite secondary schools send the same number of pupils to Oxford and Cambridge as three quarters of all the other schools in the UK. Pupils from independent schools make up 42 per cent of places at Oxbridge, and are seven t...

content.title: 市の学生が西に向かって助けて学ぶ -  ABC News
content.desc: You would be hard pressed to find two schools that have less in common, at first glance. Parramatta High School is cramped for space in busy inner-urban western Sydney, any expansion they do will have to go up in the air, as there is no space for lateral movement. The city bustles around them and school-life buzzes along within the grounds. Students have a rich multicultural heritage and diverse backgrounds, but most of them have never been west of the Nepean River. Gilgandra High School sprawls on the plains of the rural central west, in what is usually a sea of golden wheat crops at this ...

content.title: キャンペーン者は文法学校の拡張のために5千万ポンドの資金を批判 - ガーディアン
content.desc: Headteachers and campaigners for children with special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) have reacted with fury to a government announcement that 16 grammar schools are to split a £50m bonus to create new school places. Related: Councils face £536m shortfall in Send budgets, says LGA Making the announcement on Monday, the education secretary, Damian Hinds, said the 16 schools chosen to receive the additional funding out of 39 applications had been given permission to expand after setting out clear actions to prioritise access for disadvantaged children. “I have always been clear tha...

content.title: エリート・スクールは、男性と女性の生徒を劇的に異なる方法で変える -  MarketWatch
content.desc: By Jillian Berman New research looks at the effects of such schools on students’ post-college life New research shows how graduating from an elite college like Harvard can affect women’s futures. Getty Images We’re in the midst of college application season — a time when well-meaning parents and guidance counselors try to mitigate ambitious high school seniors’ stress by reminding them that an acceptance letter from an elite college won’t make or break their future. That’s essentially true, new research confirms. But it also suggests that attending an elite college could transform a young p...

content.title: 中国のナショナリズムは、儒教の学校でブームを起こす - ファイナンシャル・タイムズ
content.source_nm: ファイナンシャルタイムズ
content.desc: On a misty morning in the city of Chengdu, pre-schoolers at the Wan Hui School dutifully copy Chinese characters as a teacher identifies the origins of each symbol. “We aim to cultivate global students with Chinese qualities,” said Lan Jihong, the principal and co-founder of the school and part of a vanguard of educators behind guoxue, or Chinese “national studies”, which emphasise classical Confucian teachings. “Our responsibility is to lay a secure foundation of Chinese culture especially when students are young, in pre-school.” Although the Chinese Communist party has imposed stricter ed...

content.title: 学校は親を代用することはできません、オステッドチーフは警告します - ガーディアン
content.desc: Parents must not “abdicate their responsibility” by expecting schools to solve all the major problems children face, the chief inspector for schools will warn this week. In a robust intervention attacking the increasing burdens placed on teachers, Ofsted chief Amanda Spielman will say schools “cannot be a panacea” for all social ills and will criticise some parents for neglecting some of the “most basic of parenting tasks”, such as toilet training. While teachers “can play a role” in educating children about the dangers of knife crime and obesity, primary responsibility for these complex pr...

content.title: 高校バスケットボールの試合は、あなたが気づくまで楽しく、あなたは彼のてんかんのためのプレーヤーを嘲笑しました - フォーブス
content.desc: In the span of a few hours, a high school student and basketball fan in Greenwood, Ind., went from Twitter hero to pariah, which isn’t completely fair, in the sense that it appears that the cause of his Internet downfall really was a group effort. At 7:56 p.m. local time on Nov. 30, 2018, Indianapolis Star sports columnist Gregg Doyel, at Center Grove High School in Greenwood, Ind., to cover a big high school boys basketball game, tweeted a photo of a shirtless Center Grove fan doing the splits while wearing American flag pants, all part of his effort to led the student section in distracti...
